Name: Secure Baselines
Description: Define the expected secure state of a system. Used to detect unauthorized changes or configuration drift.

Name: Establish Baselines
Description: Create and document configurations per OS, app, and device type. Follow vendor or industry standards such as CIS Benchmarks and Microsoft Security Baselines.

Name: Deploy Baselines
Description: Use centralized deployment tools like Group Policy, MDM, or Configuration Manager. Different platforms may require unique methods.

Name: Maintain Baselines
Description: Update baselines for new vulnerabilities, OS changes, or updated standards. Continuously test and verify compliance.

Name: System Hardening
Description: Default configurations are rarely secure. Follow vendor or CIS guides to reduce attack surface.

Name: Mobile Device Hardening
Description: Use MDM for enforcement, update OS/apps, and separate work/personal data with containers or profiles.

Name: Workstation Hardening
Description: Apply updates, remove unnecessary software, and enforce policies via Group Policy or config management.

Name: Network Device Hardening
Description: Change default credentials, restrict remote management, and apply firmware and security patches.

Name: Cloud Infrastructure Hardening
Description: Use least privilege, secure management interfaces, implement EDR, and back up data to separate cloud storage.

Name: Server Hardening
Description: Apply OS and app patches, restrict services, and enable monitoring/logging.

Name: SCADA / ICS Security
Description: Industrial networks must be strictly segmented and isolated from corporate or internet networks.

Name: Embedded Systems & IoT
Description: Often difficult to patch—use network segmentation, change default credentials, and isolate on VLANs.

Name: RTOS (Real-Time Operating Systems)
Description: Used in automotive, medical, or infrastructure systems. Minimize running services and isolate communication paths.

Name: Wireless Site Surveys
Description: Identify access points, signal strength, and interference. Create heat maps for optimal coverage and performance.

Name: Wireless Survey Tools
Description: Use OS utilities, third-party analyzers, and spectrum analyzers for network visibility.

Name: Mobile Device Management (MDM)
Description: Centralized configuration and enforcement for mobile devices. Controls apps, camera, encryption, and remote wipe.

Name: BYOD (Bring Your Own Device)
Description: Employees use personal devices for work. Hard to enforce uniform security compliance.

Name: COPE (Company-Owned, Personally Enabled)
Description: Corporate devices configured for both business and limited personal use. Balances user freedom with enterprise control.

Name: Cellular Network Security
Description: Segment coverage into secure cells. Protect mobile data access using encryption and MDM.

Name: Wi-Fi Security
Description: Encrypt wireless traffic and authenticate users before granting access.

Name: Bluetooth Security
Description: Short-range communication. Avoid pairing with unknown devices to reduce risk.

Name: WPA2-PSK Weakness
Description: Vulnerable to offline dictionary attacks on captured handshakes.

Name: WPA3 Improvements
Description: Uses SAE (Simultaneous Authentication of Equals) for key exchange. Prevents brute-force attacks and adds forward secrecy.

Name: GCMP (Galois/Counter Mode Protocol)
Description: Provides AES encryption and integrity protection for wireless traffic.

Name: Wireless Authentication Modes
Description: WPA3-Personal (PSK) uses shared passphrase. WPA3-Enterprise (802.1X) authenticates users via RADIUS.

Name: AAA Framework
Description: Authentication verifies identity, Authorization defines permissions, and Accounting logs user activity.

Name: RADIUS
Description: Centralized authentication and policy enforcement service for network access.

Name: 802.1X + EAP
Description: Network Access Control requiring device authentication before network connectivity. Uses RADIUS or Kerberos.

Name: Application Security – Input Validation
Description: Always validate and sanitize user input to prevent injection attacks.

Name: Secure Cookies
Description: Use HTTPS-only cookies to protect session integrity and prevent hijacking.

Name: SAST (Static Application Security Testing)
Description: Scan source code before deployment to detect vulnerabilities early.

Name: Code Signing
Description: Digitally sign software with a private key to ensure code integrity and authenticity.

Name: Sandboxing
Description: Run code in isolated environments to limit potential system compromise.

Name: Application Security Monitoring
Description: Monitor logs, detect anomalies, and audit output to identify application-level threats.

Name: Asset Management
Description: Track all assets with ownership and lifecycle details using centralized systems and asset tags.

Name: Media Sanitization
Description: Securely remove data before disposal using wiping, degaussing, shredding, or destruction. Document with a Certificate of Destruction.

Name: Data Retention
Description: Maintain backups and archives as required for compliance and business continuity.

Name: Vulnerability Scanning
Description: Perform internal and external low-impact scans to identify weaknesses and configuration issues.

Name: Dynamic Analysis / Fuzzing
Description: Send unexpected or malformed input to detect software crashes or logic flaws.

Name: Package Monitoring
Description: Verify software package integrity and authenticity before installation or updates.

Name: Threat Intelligence Sources
Description: Includes OSINT (open-source intelligence), commercial threat feeds, and shared information via organizations like CTA.

Name: Penetration Testing
Description: Simulates real-world attacks to uncover weaknesses. Requires defined scope, methods, and rules of engagement.

Name: Attack Phases in Pen Testing
Description: Stages include initial access, lateral movement, persistence, and pivoting between systems.

Name: Vulnerability Prioritization
Description: Use CVSS scores (0–10) and CVE identifiers to rank and track vulnerabilities.

Name: Risk Considerations
Description: Evaluate exposure factor, business impact, and risk tolerance to determine remediation urgency.

Name: Mitigation & Remediation
Description: Apply patches, segment networks, and use compensating controls if patching is not possible. Verify fixes through scans.

Name: Security Monitoring & SIEM
Description: SIEM tools collect and correlate logs across systems for detection, alerting, and reporting.

Name: Alert Response
Description: Quarantine affected systems and tune alerts to reduce noise and false positives.

Name: SCAP (Security Content Automation Protocol)
Description: Standardized compliance and configuration automation framework for security validation.

Name: DLP (Data Loss Prevention)
Description: Prevents sensitive data from leaving via email, cloud, or endpoints through policy-based controls.

Name: Logging & Event Analysis
Description: Review firewall, application, endpoint, OS, IDS/IPS, and network logs. Analyze metadata and packet captures for threat investigation.
